stem: The nurse is navigating the use of digital tools for patient communication. For each method, select whether it is Generally Permitted (Secure) or Generally Prohibited (Unsecured) for transmitting ePHI under 2026 standards.

rows.text: Standard SMS (Text messaging) from a personal phone to a physician's personal phone.
Messaging within the hospital's enterprise patient portal system.
Emailing a discharge summary through a standard 'gmail.com' or 'outlook.com' address.
Virtual private network (VPN) encrypted video-calling for telehealth appointments.

rationale.correct: Encryption is the primary safeguard for digital health data. (r1 & r3) Standard SMS and consumer email are not encrypted end-to-end and are searchable/accessible by third-party providers, making them HIPAA violations. (r2 & r4) Portals and VPN-secured telehealth are designed with specific administrative and technical safeguards for medical data.
rationale.incorrect: Using personal tools for 'patient convenience' is never a defense against a privacy violation.
clinicalPearls: If a patient initiates a text message to a nurse, the nurse should politely redirect them to the secure hospital portal for all clinical matters.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Even if a patient 'consents' to be emailed via Gmail, it is still a liability risk for the nurse and hospital because it violates organizational security policies. Do not use unsecured tools.

reviewUnits.heading: Electronic Health Information (EHI) Security
reviewUnits.body: Nurses must verify that any digital tool they use has been vetted by the facility's Compliance or IT department. The 2026 standards prioritize phishing protection and data-at-rest encryption.
